Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Very Low Frequency (VLF) Remote Sensing of the Lower Ionosphere and Electron Precipitation from the Radiation Belts
Award.AbstractNarration: The nature of electrodynamic coupling between lightning discharges and the overlying ionosphere and radiation belts is explored by using (and expanding) an array of very-low-frequency (VLF) receivers known as the Holographic Array for Ionospheric/Lightning research (HAIL). That array provides high-resolution measurements of local VLF disturbances generated in the ionosphere from the receivers distributed across the continental United States at rural high schools and community colleges. The VLF disturbances are correlated with lightning data from the national Lightning Detection Network and with extremely low frequency (ELF) and VLF data from a broadband receiver in Indiana. Specific objectives include development of a physical description of thunderstorm coupling to the radiation belts, a description of electrodynamic coupling between the troposphere, mesosphere, lower ionosphere and magnetosphere, and the effect of geomagnetic storms on ionospheric variability. In addition, correlation of the HAIL VLF data with satellite measurements is used to quantify the influence of geomagnetic conditions on the loss of radiation belt electrons due to lightning generated whistler waves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Very-low-frequency (VLF) Group at Stanford University uses an array of VLF receivers known as the Holographic Array for Ionosphere and Lightning Research (HAIL) to measure ionospheric effects of lightning. Radiation from lightning can directly affect the ionosphere through direct impact ionization and heating, and indirectly through lightning-induced electron precipitation (LEP), the mechanism for which is outlined in the left column of Figure 1. Both direct and indirect effects appear as rapid perturbations to subionospheric VLF transmitter signals, as shown in the right column of Figure 1. By measuring direct effects of lightning, we hope to ascertain the physical mechanism that produces these events, and measure their effect in terms of energy and new ionization. By measuring the indirect LEP events, we can study the effects of lightning on the Earth’s magnetosphere and radiation belts, by quantifying the depletion of energetic electrons from the radiation belts due to lightning.

In the current five-year effort, we have made great discoveries with respect to LEP events. In his Ph.D thesis work, Dr. William Peter was able to quantify the loss of radiation belt electrons due to LEP events with only the VLF measurements as shown in Figure 1. He achieved this result through a combination of data analysis, studying many years’ worth of LEP events, and through detailed modeling of the physical processes that lead to electron precipitation. He found that a single lightning strike depletes a “flux tube” from the radiation belts of 0.001% of its electrons. This may seem like a small number, but often hundreds or thousands of such events occur due to a single thunderstorm. 

Following Dr. Peter’s thesis work, Dr. Ben Cotts studied the longitudinal variation of LEP events (Figure 2) and included effects of atmospheric backscatter – where electrons that seem like they should precipitate actually scatter from the top of the atmosphere and return to the magnetosphere. The longitudinal variation of LEP is primarily due to the variation in the Earth’s magnetic field over longitude. Dr. Cotts found that by including the longitudinal variations in the Earth’s magnetic field in calculations of LEP precipitation, it would be possible to estimate the global effect of LEP. 

In work related to direct effects of lightning, Dr. Cotts discovered a new class of direct events, termed “long recovery” events (Figure 3), where the ionosphere recovers from its perturbed state in tens of minutes and sometimes hours, rather than the usual 10-100 seconds. These long recoveries point to very different chemistry that is taking place in the initiation of these events. Dr. Cotts and Dr. Nikolai Lehtinen used a chemical model of the upper atmosphere to show that these long recoveries may be due to the presence of heavy negatively-charged ions in the upper atmosphere, somehow produced by the lightning discharge.

Other studies of the direct effects of lightning on the ionosphere led to the development of a new technique to study elves, which are one of the optical phenomena associated with direct ionization. Figure 4 shows elves and other optical emissions in the upper atmosphere associated with lightning. As part of his Ph.D thesis, Dr. Robert Marshall developed a new high-speed photometer array to image elves at 25,000 frames per second, resulting in the data products shown in the middle of Figure 4. He also developed a model to calculate the shape and brightness of these emissions, which matches the data very well. Dr. Robert Newsome used these elve measurements in his Ph.D thesis to determine the storm-time and global occurrence rates of elves, to study the volume of the ionosphere that they affect, and to characterize them with other parameters.
